text: It is twelve 01:00 p.m. On Wednesday, May 11, I call this meeting to order and would like to welcome all council members in attendance. Council Member Amy Peck, council Member Tasha Jackson, council Member Mary NAN Huffman, vice Chair Edward J. Pollard, vice Mayor Pro TEM Martha Castex Tatum, council Member Leticia Plummer and Council Member Sally Alcorn, and staff from Council Member Carlos Cisnero's office. And we missing Tiffany D. Thomas. Council member Tiffany D Thomas. Never miss you ever else. We'll hear about it for the rest of our lives. Before we start, vice Chair Ed Pollard. As we begin this journey, this is the first of I think we have 25 meetings, 23 individual departments, and then this analysis that we'll see this morning on the five year forecast. Any comments? No comments at this time. Immediately following the specially called BFA to go over the 2023 budget workshop, it will begin with the Finance Department presenting at 01:00 today in the Houston Fire Department presenting at 130. Additionally, the budget workshop schedule is posted on the BFA website. All budget workshops will be in person except for public speakers which have the option to comment in person or virtually. Are there any members of the public who are here in person and would like to participate? There is a sign up sheet in the front table. My staff member Carolina will be monitoring the public speakers list. As a reminder, the only people attending public or public speak virtually are public speakers. There are five virtual public speakers signed up for the public comment for this particular meeting. We will get their questions after the presentations and after questions from council members have concluded. At this time, I'd like to welcome Director Tantry Emo to provide the fiscal year 2023 budget overview and General Fund five year forecast. Also like to welcome Council Member David Robinson to the podium to the Horseshoe, and Deputy Finance Chair Will The Thrill Jones. Looking good, Will. And Council member Abby Cayman. Thank you. Thank. Good afternoon, mayor protem and council member. I don't know if you have the slides on. I am here joined by William, deputy Director William Jones. He is over the financial Planning and Analysis divisions presenting the fiscal year 2023 budget overview and General Fund five year forecast. First, I do want to recognize Mr. Jones and his limited team members. Hopefully they are all here who are here today as well as Citywide Department's financial team for pushing hard to prepare this budget on time. In front of us. Again, thank you. We do have very limited resources and I am so proud and pleased so that we can actually get this budget done timely with that. Let's go to the slides. Thank you. So again, in here we will go over the budget overview and the budget revenues and expenditures for the General fund as well as the five year forecast. And we will also go over some updates on the outcome based budgeting. Next slide. Again, this is a forward looking statement so that everybody's aware this is still based on the projections. Any changes in the futures will impact our numbers. This is again the five year forecast based on our assumptions that we can derive today. Next Slides let's start with the citywide expenditures, including debt service and pay as you go in this slide. As you see, the fiscal year 23 proposed budget for all funds, including debt service and pay as you go is at $5.7 billion. This is about $487,000,000 higher than fiscal year 22 current budget at 5.2 billion. This is an increase of 9.31%. Again, keep in mind this citywide expenditures includes total budget, includes general funds, special and enterprise funds. This does not include the surface chargeback funds, the enterprise funds, as you see in this slide, the enterprise funds accounts for about 364,000,000 of that $487,000,000 increase. If you see in here, the water and sewer had increased from 1.3 billion to 1.6 billion alone, and that is related to the consent decree and other drinking water projects. In fiscal year 23, General Fund alone accounts for about 48% of the city total funds. And as you see in here, there's a slight decrease from fiscal year 22 to reflect the total compositions of the funds from 51% to 48%. Again, because of the increased allocations on the combined utility system on the General Fund, it increased by 101,000,000, or about 3.85% increase, which we will go through more details later on next slide. Again, this is the citywide full time equivalent for civilians and classified. As you see in here, the total FTEs we have for fiscal year 23 is at 21,000, a slight decrease from fiscal year 22 current budget. Again, as mentioned by the Mayor yesterday, the fiscal year 23 proposed includes cadet classes for police and fire for five classes each. While in fiscal year 22 current budget, it includes six cadet classes for police and four cadet classes for fire. Another important notes to put in the fiscal year 23 proposed budget. In here. The general fund includes temporary employees for the Higher Houston Youth Program. So you will see some of those numbers incorporated in the General Fund FTEs. Next slide. Again, this is another deep dive of the General Fund compositions from the civilian and classified from fiscal year 15 to fiscal year 23. Again, another thing to point in here, keep in mind the fiscal year 2020 and fiscal year 21 FTEs seems to be lower. Again, this is due to the redeployment that was funded out of CRF at that time. Next slide. So this is the American rescue plan act. As you all know, this fiscal year 23 proposed budget also includes funding from the ARPA, similar to what we did last year. Again, this is just a reminder. ARPA was signed into law March 11, 2021, providing 65.1 billion federal funding. Our portion for the City of Houston is about $607.8 million in two tranches. So we received the first tranche last year around May of $303,000,000. So we will be expecting the second tranche sometime this month. Hopefully we have not yet received it. It is typically stated to be twelve months after the first tranche. The city would have until December 31, 2024 to use the fund. Again. Unlike CRF, ARPA recognizes the economic impact due to the COVID-19 pandemic and provides flexibility to address reductions in revenues due to the COVID-19 Public health emergency. The Coronavirus State and Local Fiscal Recovery Fund final rule was available by the US. Treasury. Released on January 2022. So this budget includes 160.1 million in the ARPA utilization for the provisions of the government services relative to the revenue reductions due to COVID-19 public health emergency. Next slide. Okay, so a quick overview of the General Fund that we are proposing today. This budget includes 13.5% fund balance of the expenditures, less debt service and pay as you go, which is above the desired minimum of 7.5%, and that is about $138,000,000 above the 7.5%. This budget includes 3% pay raises for the municipal employees, 6% pay raises for the firefighters and 4% pay raises for the police. Classified this proposed budget fully fund the budget stabilization fund. So right now we are over $20 million set aside for the Budget Stabilization Fund. Again, as mentioned, this funds for cadet classes, five cadet classes each in police and fire, and also fully fund all three pension systems. So this budget does not include fund balance drawdown, nor one time land sales, nor payment deferrals. So let's start with the General Fund revenues. So this is the net change of the General Fund revenues including other sources. So that includes sale of land and transfers. Compared to the fiscal year 22 estimates, the proposed budget increased by about 2.4%. So our 2.7 million compared to the fiscal year 22 estimates of 2.67 million. Let's start with the biggest increase which is from the bottom, which is property tax, $48.8 million increase. And again, this is based on Proposition One and H limitations that we have, which is based on the populations plus CPI. Keep in mind the CPI is already available at this point at 4.8%. The population is still at 0% assumptions waiting until the US census Bureau released it sometimes in May. Intergovernmental this has increased by 10.4 million compared to fiscal year 22 estimates. Again, this is where you see the use of the ARPA funding, which is 160,000,000 compared to fiscal year 22. We use about 139 million. So roughly those are increases in the intergovernmental. We also reflect transfer from other funds increased by 3.8 million. This is mainly from the Park Houston funds. As economies start going back to normal, so you will see some of those parking fees generated and so the transfers start coming to increase in fiscal year 23 charges for services, this is increased due to higher than anticipated digital network and network notes. We also have others that is noted in here. This is because of the interest you see all those low interest in last year. But now with the increased cash that we have, we are projecting an increased interest in our fiscal year 23. Another decrease in here I'm going to go through the decreases is the franchise fees. This is again mainly on the telephone franchise that continues to decline. Next slide. Again, this is just a composition allocations in the general fund revenue categories between fiscal year 23 proposed and fiscal year 22 estimates. Again the biggest chunk that we have in our revenue sources are two. Property tax and sales tax continue to be our primary sources that compose about 67 70% of the general fund. We also have the other funds and franchise fees as noted in here. Again, keep in mind this revenues includes the funding from ARPA of 160,000,000 in the intergovernmental. Next slide. Again, this is just another different look on a bar chart and you could see the comparison from fiscal year 15 all the way to fiscal year 23 proposed budget for the property tax, sales tax, franchise and other revenues. You could see some of those dip in fiscal year 2020 and 21 slight movement because again because of the COVID Next slide on the property tax revenues. Again this is based on the estimated taxable value of $289,000,000,000, which is an increase of 8.98%. This estimated taxable value is the net off the tax incremental agreements which is 246.2 billion. Again, population data from the US Census Bureau as of July 1 has yet to be received. So our property tax revenues in here is only based on the CPI index of 4.3%. I misspoke, I said 4.8 is 4.28% initially and we will adjust this calculations once the US Census Bureau data is available by the end of May. So with that the increased property tax revenues is at 3.97%, which is 48.9 million higher than fiscal year 22 estimates. Again, this is still based on the over 65 and disabled exemptions at 160,000 and I know Mayor had mentioned yesterday that he proposed to increase that over 65 and disabled exemptions from 160,000 to 260,000 in a separate council actions, sometimes in June. Next slide again, so this is based on the budget versus actual of the property tax revenues from fiscal year 19 to fiscal year 23. Again, the adopted budget since fiscal year 15 is based on the proposition one plus H and you could see the delta between those with the actual. So fiscal year 22 estimates right now is not projected to be changing, so we are still remaining our projections at the revenue cap and again fiscal year 23 proposed budget is also at the revenue cap. Next slide. And you've seen this before, this is just a chart to show the impact of the charter cap to what we have at this time since fiscal year 17. So again since fiscal year 19 we already hit the property revenue cap where we were based on the populations plus CPI growth in our revenues. But if we did not have that so you could see in here the impact of that is about 1.4 billion from fiscal year 15. The impact of the prop the revenue cap we have for fiscal year 23 as you see in there is at $282,000,000. Next slide. Thank you. Moving on to the sales tax revenues. Again, we are conservative as we are heading into fiscal year 23 budget. So we keep our percentage growth for sales tax flat. This estimate reflect an improvement to the economic conditions compared to fiscal year 2021 which was severely impacted by COVID-19 Pandemic which affected our national and global economy. So although the energy sector has contributed significantly to the Houston economy, the ongoing volatility of the Russian's invasions of Ukraine has caused uncertainties among the oil industry. So current average oil price is at 109.77 per barrel. This is as of May 6. So therefore the proposed budget assumes no growth from the fiscal year 22 estimates. And when we look at Dr. Gilmer which is our consultants on the sales tax and the economists who's from the Institute for Regional Forecasting at the UFH, he projected the fiscal year 23 range for the city sales tax ranging from the low of 773 to 812,000,000. So we are somewhat in the middle at this point. Again, it's a lot of moving factors going forward. So we want to be conservative and just we leave it as flat at this point from fiscal year 22 estimates we had seen, of course, as you all see it every single month are projecting increasing in the sales tax as we receive more receipts in this year. But again, we don't know what we don't know. So we want to leave it flat at this time. Next slide. Okay, so this is the trends on the sales tax. Again, sales tax is very volatile. It changes very quickly as the economy shifted. You see what happened with the Pandemic. So with the drop in state home, so that revenues which would decrease tremendously. So again comparison from fiscal year 19 where we are at with our sales tax. So now we're moving on to the John Fund expenditures. So again, this is the net change from fiscal year 20 to current budget. So we are reflecting about 3.85% increase in the general fund of 2.7 billion compared to the 2.6 billion major changes we have in there is on the operating budget. Again, it includes the employee compensations. So that is an increase of 44.6 million. So that is on the fire, police and municipal pay raises also have the surface chargeback funds. This is restricted accounts of 18.35 million health benefits includes about 14.7 million increases in here other surface chargeback and I know we put that note in there is for the contract escalations and new facility operating cost we also project some savings in this proposed budget, mainly on the pension. So you see the pension and note four showing a reduction of 2.3 million. This is because of the rate changes from the midpoint to the minimum point for the fire pension as they are falling below the minimum corridor at this point. And also deferral. If you recall our budget in fiscal year 2000 and 22,021 includes deferral for the Walker lease building. So now we don't have deferral anymore. So we only pay what we are owed on an annual basis. So that shows some saving on the debt service and payers to go, it increased by 22.6 million. Again, some of that is pertaining to the captured revenues pay go as increase in the CPIs included in that calculation as well and also transfer of the debt service. Now this does not include any prepayment from the building inspections. If you recall our previous budget includes debt prepayment for the building inspection funds. So this is not including that. So you will see some of those uptick because of no longer debt prepayment from the building inspections included in this debt service transfers. Next slide. Okay, again, this is just a comparison of the allocated general fund expenditures including debt service from fiscal year 23 to fiscal year 22. Again, public safety still remains the bulk of the compositions in the general fund. Police and fire alone is at $1.55 billion. So compared to this $2.7 billion proposed budget, police and fire alone includes about 56.4% of the total budget. Another one that I want to point out in here is the debt service or the debt service which is pledged with the property tax revenues that we have is about 13% of our general fund budget. 3% is the pay as you go and you see the remaining is those other departments including Solid Waste. I think Solid Waste is in one of those other departments. Next slides. So this is the compositions of the personnel versus non personnel. Now overall again our general fund, 62% is personnel, I know we kind of mentioned that earlier, 62% is personnel, 38% is in others. Out of that 62 personnel, 76 of that is classified police and fire. Only 24% is civilians. Again, going back to the others portion of the 38% debt service is about 42%. You have the energy costs in there and other service and chargeback. Next slide. So this is a slide just to go through the general fund pension contributions. I know Mayor had mentioned the pension reform was done in 2017. So from the unfunded liability point of view, the pension reform in 2017 reduced the projected unfunded liability from 8.2 billion to 1.5 billion. That is reduction about 6.7 billion from the liability point of view. But what you see in here in this chart is the projected city pension contributions without the reform. So if you look at this, the shaded area in there without the reform we would have had to set aside another 1.4 billion on the operating funds to pay for those city contributions. Again, the full impact from stiscalyte 18 on the city general fund contribution is about 1.4 billion, if not because of the pension reform. Next slide so finally, this is the general fund unassigned ending fund balance. So as mentioned, so we are now at 13.46% 13.5%. We are at 310.7 million fund balance. So that is about $138,000,000 above the 7.5%. But one thing I do want to note in here, the fiscal year 22 and the fiscal year 23 fund balance in here includes ARPA funding that is not recurring. So I cannot stress enough on the important to preserve fund balance because of what's coming ahead in fiscal year 25. Another thing to put in here, fiscal year 18 amount requires 7.5%. Fund balance is adjusted to exclude the 910,000,000 pension obligation bond. This is back in fiscal year 18. Next slide. So now we're moving to the general fund five year forecast. Again, this is a forecast which has some assumptions in the next five years at this point, but hopefully it would give some ideas of where we're going to be in the next five years. Again, this projected gap range based on the conservative and optimistic growth in revenues, it does not include any one time land sales for our revenues property tax revenues. It is in compliance with Propositions One and Eight limitations holding. The senior disabled exemptions at 160,000 and the pension assumption is based on and this is to be corrected based on either minimum or midpoint of the corridor because of the conditions of those pension groups on the expenditures. Also includes legal mandates, staffing for new facilities and contractual escalators starting with the revenues. Next slide. So I've talked about what is in the assumptions for the fiscal year 23 proposed budget. So roughly, property tax growth is about 4%. Again, the driver of that is the CPI is the CPI growth rate. We have not including any populations growth rate. So this is still based on the 0% populations which will be updated once we have this data by the end of May. Again, sales tax growth rates in fiscal year 23 remain flat. Franchise fees overall its reduction of 1.2%. Again, bulk of that is the telephone franchise fees that continues to decline. We also have other revenue growth at 3.7%. This is on the Industrial Assessment license and permits as we have seen some revenue increases in fiscal year 22 as the economy started to pick up and no one time land sales in here. So you see the projection from fiscal year 24 to 27, which is based on the low and the high for our assumptions. Next slide. On the expenditure side, again, we've gone through the fiscal year 23 assumptions. Police is based on a 4% increase, fire is based on a 6% increase, pay raises, municipal Employees is based on a 3% increase and we've gone through the pension contributions for fiscal year 23 which is known at this point, is at the 8.44 for Hmaps which is based on the midpoint. Again, we also have the legacy pension that we have to pay to Hmaps at 142,000,000. H Pops is based on 31.98, which is the midpoint at this point, and the Fire pension at 26.89 which is at the minimum point of the corridor. We have the growth assumption for health benefits at 4%, which is known at this point. And again the debt service and pays you go as described earlier. Now going to fiscal year 24 to 27, this is our assumptions going forward. We know what has already been in the meet and confer with police which is 3% 24 and 3.5% 25. So we're not using any assumptions in the future at this point, which is at TBD. At this point Fire is 6% in 24 and TBD. So we just remain at that point for these assumptions and another 3% in 24 for municipal employees. Again, H maps for 24 to 27 is based on the midpoint of corridor. Police and Fire is going to be looking at the minimum. So we have a range of minimum and midpoint because they are getting close to the minimum corridor. So we are making some assumptions at this point because it's still a moving number. So we're making this range for police and Fire again on the health benefits because it's still assumptions going forward. We also do a range on the growth for the health benefits five to 7% and the debt service of course is based on our debt service models which is planned payment for the next five years. So with that we go to the next slide so we could map this out and take a look at what the gap is going to look like. Next slide, please. So this is roughly what we're looking at in the next five years. Keep in mind this does not include ARPA funding so I don't want to skew our visibility with mixing the ARPA funding in these discussions. As you see in fiscal year 23 you have about $160,000,000 gap so that's what ARPA funding came in and fiscal year 24 does not include ARPA fundings in this scenario as well. So that is something that we will be incorporating in next fiscal year and going forward you have an idea what our range of gap looks like. Again, this is not using any utilizations of ARPA funding. Next slide. So let's take a look back and see what have we done as a city. I know you've all seen the PFM studies and so I do want to put forth what has been done to see where we are at today because if this is not done then we would have been in a much worse situations at this point. So one thing's first of course is the pension reform that was done 2017. You saw what the impact if that was not done in that city contributions and unfunded liabilities, OPAP reform. So we had seen some reductions in the unfunded liabilities. Shared services we have done on the joint processing center. We have shared services with the Harris County, of course, continuing hiring control through the Mayor staffing Efficiencies program. You've seen all the claw back provisions that we had implemented a couple of years ago. You've seen the EMSC adjustments that went to council several years ago as well. And of course the health benefits update, negotiated Cdwat medical and prescriptions benefits plans, implemented Spousal surcharge if you've all seen it, and also perform the dependent eligibility audit and there's maybe other stuff that has been done. So these are the major items that I do want to highlight before we go to the next slides. Next slide. So again, what's next? Again, it's important to understand what we work with at this point. We do have the limitations on the property tax revenue cap, in city charter and state cap. So not just the city's local cap, but there's also state cap that we have to work and comply with. Another limitation is public safety. It is something to note that police and fire costs make up about 57% of the general fund and also COVID impact. So which is the economic uncertainties that we are dealing with at this point. COVID and of course what happened in Russian invasions to Ukraine. So that would impact the oil prices, again, the volatility in the economy. So on the short terms, it is important for us to build and preserve fund balance. Again, to be conservative, continue to leverage ARPA funding, to address revenue losses, continue hiring control and also look for efficiencies and cost cutting opportunities, developing new revenue sources. And I briefly mentioned that in the press conference yesterday. And again continue working day one to build the fund balance as we had into fiscal year 23, 24 and 25. In the long terms, again, continue to look into those implementing PFM recommendations that are supported by both mayor and yourself, city Council in which one of that, as you had seen in the past, is the outcome based budgeting. So we are in the progress to do that. And so with that we have an update on the outcome based budgeting and I would refer to Deputy Director William Jones. All right. Thank you, Director. And to Mayor Pro TEM and Council. Time to switch pace a little bit, talk about something a little fun, at least it is to me. So this is a project I've been very close to since this is a project I've been close to since about 2011 twelve. We've been making small incremental progress throughout the years, but now I'm excited that we've actually launched this project. So last summer we kicked off phase one of the outcome based budgeting project. So if you can bring up the slides please. Okay, so in phase one, it was essentially a discovery phase. So we brought in the consultant to come in and look at our process, look at our systems, look at our technology, and do an assessment. And with that, we had a lot of workshops with the departments. And like I said, throughout the years we had already been working with the departments, making what progress we could on what our programs and how do we start looking at our budget a little differently. From phase one, we conducted 45 workshops. We had over 100 plus participants. All 26 departments participated, and we were able to identify hundreds of programs. And we also looked at some different vendors on some technology solutions. So phase one was a very successful phase. So when you look at what does it mean to implement it successfully, what do we have to do? So we focused on three key things the people, technology and process. So those are some of the findings and recommendations that we looked at. So when you look at the people, one of the most important things is to have buy in at the very top, at the very top level with the mayor. And we definitely have to buy in from the mayor. One of the first things he did when he came in the office is signed Executive Order 150, which pretty much outlined a performance based budget model that the city would move towards. And we also have buy in from council. I know Councilman Alcorn has been very involved with it. We had an amendment, I want to say a couple of years ago that we would start that discovery phase. So we did complete that. And then not only at the top level, we have to have engagement with the employees, the managers, the people that are actually doing the work. And again, we've been doing that. So we want to keep that momentum that we've had throughout the year. So even with this budget, I work with departments to make sure they are thinking about their budget in terms of programs, have them start thinking of how they would measure those things. And I'll show you a really good example later in this presentation. So people is very important. Also technology. One of the things I found throughout my time of reviewing outcome based budget and performance based budget is that technology was a huge barrier for a lot of cities. I think now is the perfect time that the technology has advanced so much in the past five years. A lot of cloud based solutions, a lot of solutions that will allow us to track performance. And I presented with TTI, I think last month, along with his department, that we have found a solution that may work for us. So the technology, like I said, is a very important part. And we've made a lot of progress. The industry has made a lot of progress on that front. And probably one of. The most important thing is the process. So that's one of the key things we focused on, making sure because it's a major shift for the city to go from the incremental based budgeting to looking more at performance and focusing on outcomes. So process is one of the things we're going to spend a lot of time on in the second phase. Next slide please. So what's next? So the next phase, one of the first things, like I said, is focusing on the process. So redesign and introduce our budget process, starting with the strategic plan. So one of the major differences with outcome based budget is you start with your strategic plan, what are the outcomes that the citizens expect, what are the priorities of the city, and then we build from there. So we build our budget knowing what those goals are so that you know how to prioritize your budget and build your budget from the ground up. So in this next phase, it's going to be very important that we developed our process, document our process, change our budget calendar. We have to look at what new forms do we need to create. So that's going to be to me one of the most important process before we even get to the system, because you don't want to get a system and then you're still trying to figure out your process. You want to get a system, have your process in place and transition all that over first. So we're going to focus on process first and then you see on the second bullet, then we're going to look at implementing a comprehensive budget solution so that's the technology and the system that I talked about. And when you look at bullet point number three, then we integrate all of those solutions together, the process with the system and making sure everything works together. And then on number four, again, as I said, one of the most important things is people making sure that the employees, the managers, understand their role in this new budgeting format, understand that we need to track performance. A lot of departments already do it, but it doesn't drive decisions. So we're going to need to change that mentality to make sure that they're tracking performance for the outcomes that we expect and that we're monitoring those and measuring those. And then again, redefine the talent, provide staff with the support and resources that they need to be able to do that. This is not an easy thing and from what I've seen with other cities, they do have challenges. So we need to make sure that the staff has the support that they need to be able to track the goals and build the budget and have that buy in from the leadership to know that we're all moving in the same direction. Okay, so the next slide. So this is the one I really wanted to focus on to show you some of the work that we've done. So this is real data that we did with the Hits department. So it's a prototype, but it's based on real data. So we took their revolving fund budget, which is 98.1 million. So what they did, if you look at the very bottom, you'll see the programs. So we identified about 13 programs within the Hits department. So if you're looking at it, you can see how much more relevant that the data is here. When you're looking at the budget, you can see looking at the first one citywide customer service, three one one program. People may not know that the Hits involvement with the Three One one program. And when we look at it from a global perspective, well, you know, three one one is in Ara as well. And then the goal is to be able to show how much are we spending on three one one. Then you start measuring what is the call time, how long does it take to respond, and then you can start measuring that to see, okay, are we performing accurately or do we need to put more money there or do we need to reassess? And then how long does it take for responses to be responded to by other departments? But until we have it's difficult to see in our current budget. But if we have program called Three one One that crosses other departments and we can see the total cost of what it is to run a three one one program, then we can make better decisions on how we fund those programs. So like I said, altogether it's about 13 programs there. And then you go up to the next level. Now we're going to tie those programs into the priorities because right now, we don't know how much we're spending on the priorities of the city. So that'll be one of the big changes. And then you go up to the next level, and then we tie it to the plan. Houston, the core strategies, that the citizen survey, that what they expect. Right now, we can't tell them how much are we spending on sustaining quality infrastructure. Like I said, right now we're just looking at Hits. But once we get this entire thing up and running, then we can provide the citizens with better data to be able to understand where their dollars are going and also provide council with better information on how we can make decisions and fund these things. So like I said, I'm very excited that we've kicked this project off officially. Phase two is going to like it's going to be a challenge. So the goal is we're still aiming for FY 24 with the hopes of for sure having the process in place. Now, the system may take a little more time, but like I said, the process is the most important part. But we're definitely going to get a system, but without the process, to me, the system can wait, but we're moving forward with both. So by FY 24, we'll have some form of outcome based budgeting to present to you guys. So on the next slide, and this just shows you kind of how our reporting would look taking that same data with hits, you can see, you get the program description, what are the goals of that program, and then you'll see now we're starting to put measures tying it to those programs. And then throughout the year, we would have to track, are we hitting those targets? If not, then what do we need to do? So it's a different way of looking at your budget, not focusing on how much do we spend on this department, how much do we spend on that department, but what are the programs that we're providing to the citizens and how are they performing. So my hope is that not only do we change, provide the citizens with better information on how their dollars are being spent, but also kind of change how council can look at the budget and get away from the little line items here and there and the department spending there, and focus on those programs and start paying attention to what we're measuring. Okay, I think that's it for that. So before I turn it over to questions, I do want to take a moment to recognize my team. I had them put on their Sunday's Best in March over here. So I'm going to ask them to stand up, team. Stand up, all of you. These are the people that work nights and weekends to get this budget done. And all I had to do is bribe them with a little food and they put in the work. So to say I'm proud of them would be a huge understatement. And I've had the highest number of vacancies I've ever had going into a budget cycle, so they did triple the workload. And I am extremely proud of this group here. So thank you guys. The last 15 years I've been with the city, I think this is the least amount of teams we have to do the budget. So I'm very proud. Thank you so much. Retention. Retention.
